p: In 2016, remdesivir (GS-5734) was reported to be active against Ebola virus in multiple human cell types, including primary macrophages and human endothelial cells, with low half-maximal effective concentration (EC 50) values of 0.06–0.14 μM [15]. In addition, remdesivir was reported to exhibit antiviral activity in vitro against Marburg virus [15], Paramyxoviridae (such as parainfluenza type 3 virus, Nipah virus, Hendra virus, and measles and mumps viruses) and Pneumoviridae (such as respiratory syncytial virus) [19].
